segments.text: Thanks for grabbing coffee with me, Marcus. I wanted to pick your brain about the album.
Always! So you're in the home stretch now, right? How's it feeling?
It's feeling good, but I'm second-guessing myself on a couple production choices. You know how it is.
Oh for sure. Every artist goes through that. What specifically are you worried about?
The mix on track three. It's very dense, lots of layers. I'm worried it's going to sound cluttered on streaming platforms.
Have you tested it on different playback systems? Like phone speakers, car stereos?
Just on my studio monitors and headphones. I should probably do that, shouldn't I?
Definitely. I always check my mixes in my car. If it sounds good on crappy car speakers, it'll sound good anywhere.
That's smart. I'll do that tomorrow. What about loudness? I'm trying to avoid the loudness war trap.
Good instinct. Streaming platforms normalize everything anyway. I'd aim for around -14 LUFS and preserve the dynamics.
Yeah, that's where I'm at. I want it to breathe. The quiet parts should be quiet.
Exactly. That's what makes music interesting. Constant loud is fatiguing to listen to.
Okay, you're making me feel better about my choices. One more thing - mastering. Should I master it myself or send it out?
I always send it out. Fresh ears catch things you miss when you've been living with the tracks for months.
Yeah, you're probably right. Do you have any mastering engineers you'd recommend?
Sarah Chen. She did my last three albums. She's incredible with indie stuff, really understands dynamics.
Perfect, I'll reach out to her. Thanks Marcus, this really helped.
Anytime. Can't wait to hear the finished album. You're going to kill it.

environment.background_sounds: cafe ambiance, espresso machine, background chatter, cups clinking
